Entries.default: "We can summon the guards if you want to be difficult, aimico. Kindly leave."
"If Luca doesn't see reason, the Duape will lose their lands! For their sake, I must-"
"That's enough out of you. Good day."
"What seems to be the problem?"
"Not yet, at least. Why?"

"My people are the Duape. We signed a contract with the company." 

Tawenu looks toward the headquarters with a despondent frown.
"I'm guessing the company didn't like someone challenging their unfair deal."
"Please, I must ask for a favor." He shies back from making eye contact, keeping his head lowered.
"If you were kicked out, I'd wager it was for a good reason."
"I did not provoke anger, I say. This is not just."
"Tell me more about this contract."

"My father, the ranga, took payment from the company. In exchange, they dig for adra." 

He speaks with more confidence, as if these words were rehearsed several times over.
"He did not understand the Vailian way. When he dies, the outlanders will claim our island for themselves."
"Father has fallen ill. And the clerk, Luca, stands by the agreement as surely as if it was stamped in his skin."
"Your father's a poor negotiator. Not my problem."

"Not so. Father remembered what outsiders do when the Huana do not cooperate." 

Tawenu's concerned expression hardens as he regards the company headquarters.
"May the fish leap into your boat, brother."
Entries.female: "May the fish leap into your boat, sister."

Entries.default: "That's a bold proposal if I ever heard one."
"So what's your plan?"
"I made appeals to Luca, but my words were as stones dropped down the deepest well."
"I'll meet with this Luca. Maybe we can arrive at more agreeable terms."
"Good luck with that. It's got nothing to do with me."
"The sound of struggle reached my ears. You did not come to blows with the clerk?"
"I did kill him, if that's what you mean."
"It does not help my people if the company seeks vengeance on us!"
"They will hunt the Duape down like eels, I say! I cannot make haste fast enough!"
"You bring ruin to the Duape!"

"While I am barred from the company office, I can do nothing for my people." 

Tawenu worries one of the many tassels adorning his garb.
"I'll look into it, but I make no promises."
"My words were only the crashing of waves. You will speak with authority, I say."
"The company has problems with us, I say. We are in sad times."

"Ekera, my thanks! I will remain here by day until justice is done." 

The worst of his concerns are quickly overshadowed by a broad smile.

"Ekera, my luck ran out some time ago." 

He seems poised to say more, but stops himself.
"The company may see you as a spy. Take care that your oar doesn't cut the waves too sharply."
"Ekera. When the Vailian clerk learned I was from the Duape, he became very anxious."
"Can't help you, friend. Sorry."
"What can I do for you?"
"On second thought, I'll return later."
"I will be going nowhere, my friend. The clerk and all of his harmful words could not move me."
"I'm siding with Luca. The Duape should prepare to leave their island."
"Luca may never understand how it happened, but your village is free."

"Ekera, I... cannot believe! A light after our long sorrow." 

His smile broadens and Tawenu slaps your shoulder with encouragement.
"I talked some sense into Luca. Your people's lands are safe."
"My village is modest, but I came prepared. I set aside a few gems for trading. They are yours by right."
"Thank you. I'll accept whatever payment you have to offer."
"Hold on to it. Teaching the Vailian Trading Company a lesson was well worth the effort."
"Seashells from the natives. Isn't this... quaint."
"You are a friend to the Duape. We do not forget." Tawenu smiles, rolling his shoulder with the ease of one who stands suddenly taller.

"You are no friend of the Huana, I say!" 

He takes a cautious step back, shaking his head.
"I... do not understand. You aid the company at the cost of our people?"
"You're not 'my people'. We just look alike."
"I can't buy new boots with cultural solidarity."
"Just get out of here."
"This is a city of terrible people driven to do terrible things! I leave before it corrupts me further."
"I've done business with them, if that's what you mean."
"Ekera, you can help me, I say! They will listen to you."
"Tell your ranga that his village is safe from the outsiders."
"A strange smell follows you, I say. I hope you are not unwell?"
"Forget the smell. Your village is safe from the Vailian Trading Company."
"Why did they kick you out of their office?"
"I showed Luca a new contract, yes? Fairer, more agreeable terms."
"Mind if I take a look at the... 'new' contract?"
"Luca has it secured in a chest. Tangaloa's jaws, such trouble for parchment, I say."
"I wish to... what say, 'renegotiate?' But the clerks turn me away."
"Ekera, already this treatment is not so unusual."
"Luca called me a criminal and summoned his guards." Tawenu lets his arms hang down by his sides.
He tries to hold your gaze, but his expression breaks into a mask of regret and despair.
"This is all? I assume you paid for food in Neketaka. Give me whatever you have left."
"It... it is not much, I apologize, but here." With a shaking hand he passes you a paltry sum of coins.
Your patronizing tone elicits a flicker of doubt, but otherwise Tawenu beams with pride.
[Say nothing.]
"You are a friend in need, I say."
"The city plants hope and grows sorrow, I say."
"What say, do you have business with the Vailian Trading Company?"
"What did you mean by a 'new' contract?"
"Back to my previous questions."
"Negotiating with outsiders has not gone my way." Tawenu scratches the back of his head, frowning.
"A man in the Gullet offered to assist me. He carried papers, ink, and wax."
"He helped to write a new contract in the Vailian way and affix the correct seals."

"Luca, I say he did not like this. He took my contract and forced me into the streets." 

Tawenu gestures to the spot on which he stands.
[Truth] "I'm pretty sure you were given a forgery."
[Lie] "That was very unjust of Luca."
"I... do not know this word. I would fix, but Luca will not give me the chance."
"Ekera, you say true? My belly has ached for having insulted him."
"Ekera, you return! What say, friend?" Tawenu touches his brow in greeting.
"You're welcome, brother."
"Mother Ngati plays with our hopes, I say." Sparing a pained glance at Tekēhu, he wipes his eyes and leaves.
"Why didn't you tell me that you showed Luca a fake contract?"
"Fake? What say?" His lips press together in a frown of concern.
"I spoke to Luca. He doesn't make it easy, does he?"
"Ekera, he holds fast to his responsibilities and bends for no man or woman."
"Do you know anything about Luca that we could use to our advantage?"
"His breath smells of drink, I say. A foreigner's weakness." Tawenu wrinkles his nose in distaste.
"Stubbornness is admired among his people, I say."
"I suppose their office has to close some time..."
"What say, you walk with the paws of a big cat?" Tawenu leans in closer to whisper.
"Luca keeps contracts in a separate room. An office for parchment."
"Luca enjoys his wine... perhaps too much."
"A guard did whisper that Luca frequents the public house." Tawenu glances toward the tavern to the east.
"Ekera, it may be that cooperation lies at the bottom of Luca's glass?" Tawenu touches his lips - intrigued, but uncertain.
"The Vailians will lock away anything, I say. Even their paperwork." Tawenu glances up at the headquarters and sighs.
"I'm still trying to restore the Duape land rights."
"Ekera, my thanks." Tawenu's smile falters.
"No charge."
"I'm a legal clerk myself. If I'm going to represent you, I'll need payment up front."

"Ekera, the gods have steered us together, friend! Take all that you need to get started."

He dumps two palmfuls of coppers into your hands.
The young Huana wears a disconcerted frown. He meets your approach with the flicker of a welcoming smile, but it dies down quickly.
"May Amira's wings fill your sail." He touches two fingers to his forehead and sighs.
"Will you be speaking with the Vailian Trading Company... friend?" The young Huana swallows, his brow furrowed.
"We were not understanding the terms at the time."
"Daughter of Amira, you are knowing of these things?" He glances toward Pallegina, blinking with wonder.
"I am not a daughter of Amira. And yes, I know of them. I cannot know the details of the contract without seeing it myself, but it sounds quite ordinary for the Company."
"Too many big words for you, friend? Next time hire an advocate."
Opening his mouth to retort, Tawenu instead takes in Maia with confusion before turning back to you.
"A cruel practice, I say. And they call us savages."
"Ngati's chosen speaks with the wisdom of his mother." Tawenu touches his brow and inclines his head.
"Wow. You are clearly your father's son."
"No matter the end, I will not forget the kindness."
"Who will help the Duape if not gods or neighbors?" Sighing, Tekēhu smooths back his hair.
"Luca listened to reason. The Duape will keep their island."
"Then he is a good clerk. He wouldn't be much use to the Company if he didn't look after their interests."
"Then I must be a good son, and look after the interests of the Duape."
"Vailia makes the work of conquering you people look easy." Maia clucks her tongue and grins to herself.
"Their words are poison, I say. As are yours."
"I will tell my people that Ngati's chosen brought hope to the Huana." He touches his brow with special reverence for Tekēhu.
"Feel free to keep me out of it, I say!" Tekēhu glances away, biting the inside of his cheek.
